items.title: Canada’s Carney says he apologised to Trump over Reagan anti-tariff ad

items.content: Canadian PM says anti-tariff ad featuring Ronald Reagan 'offended' Trump, who has since cut off trade talks with Canada.

items.title: Canada's prime minister apologises to Trump over anti-tariff advert
items.standfirst: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has apologised to Donald Trump over an anti-tariff advert featuring a clip of Ronald Reagan.
items.content: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has apologised to Donald Trump over an anti-tariff advert featuring a clip of Ronald Reagan.

items.title: Canada's Mark Carney apologizes to Trump over anti-tariff ad
items.standfirst: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has said he apologized to President Donald Trump for an Ontario government ad that used Ronald Reagan’s words to criticize Trump’s trade policy.“I did apologize,” Carney told reporters on Saturday after attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Gyeongju, South Korea
items.content: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has said he apologized to President Donald Trump for an Ontario government ad that used Ronald Reagan’s words to criticize Trump’s trade policy.“I did apologize,” Carney told reporters on Saturday after attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Gyeongju, South Korea

items.title: Era of free trade and investment is over, Canada’s PM tells Apec summit
items.standfirst: Mark Carney warns Asia-Pacific leaders global economy undergoing profound change, as China’s president mounts defence of free tradeThe Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, has warned that the era of free trade and investment that formed the foundations of the postwar global economy has ended.In a stark message to Asia-Pacific leaders at the Apec summit in South Korea on Friday, Carney said rules-based open trade no longer worked in a global economy that was undergoing one of its most profound periods of change since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. Continue reading...
items.content: Mark Carney warns Asia-Pacific leaders global economy undergoing profound change, as China’s president mounts defence of free tradeThe Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, has warned that the era of free trade and investment that formed the foundations of the postwar global economy has ended.In a stark message to Asia-Pacific leaders at the Apec summit in South Korea on Friday, Carney said rules-based open trade no longer worked in a global economy that was undergoing one of its most profound periods of change since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney apologized to President Donald Trump over an anti-tariff advertisement.
The ad, featuring Ronald Reagan, criticized Trump's trade policies and led to cancelled trade talks.
Ontario's Premier Doug Ford was advised by Carney not to run the ad.
Trump suggested trade talks would not restart after receiving the apology from Carney.
The apology occurred at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in South Korea.

The suspects were charged with organized crime and being an accomplice, respectively.
Four people are now charged in connection to the theft of the jewels.
The suspects were arrested earlier in the week and have denied involvement.
The total value of the stolen jewelry is estimated at £76 million.

items.title: Trump threatens to go into Nigeria ‘guns-a-blazing’ over attacks on Christians
items.standfirst: US president says he ordered Pentagon to begin planning for action, without mentioning Muslim persecutionDonald Trump on Saturday said he had ordered the Pentagon to begin planning for potential military action in Nigeria as he stepped up his criticism that the government was failing to rein in the persecution of Christians in the west African country.“If the Nigerian Government continues to allow the killing of Christians, the USA will immediately stop all aid and assistance to Nigeria, and may very well go into that now disgraced country, ‘guns-a-blazing,’ to completely wipe out the Islamic Terrorists who are committing these horrible atrocities,” Trump posted on social media. “I am hereby instructing our Department of War to prepare for possible action. If we attack, it will be fast, vicious, and sweet, just like the terrorist thugs attack our CHERISHED Christians!” Continue reading...
items.content: US president says he ordered Pentagon to begin planning for action, without mentioning Muslim persecutionDonald Trump on Saturday said he had ordered the Pentagon to begin planning for potential military action in Nigeria as he stepped up his criticism that the government was failing to rein in the persecution of Christians in the west African country.“If the Nigerian Government continues to allow the killing of Christians, the USA will immediately stop all aid and assistance to Nigeria, and may very well go into that now disgraced country, ‘guns-a-blazing,’ to completely wipe out the Islamic Terrorists who are committing these horrible atrocities,” Trump posted on social media. “I am hereby instructing our Department of War to prepare for possible action. If we attack, it will be fast, vicious, and sweet, just like the terrorist thugs attack our CHERISHED Christians!” Continue reading...

"If the Nigerian Government continues to allow the killing of Christians, the U.S.A. will immediately stop all aid…
items.content: President Donald Trump in a message posted to Truth Social on Saturday threatened to go into Nigeria "guns-a-blazing" to attack Islamic terrorists if Nigeria does not deal with them. "If the Nigerian Government continues to allow the killing of Christians, the U.S.A. will immediately stop all aid…

ai_summary: President Trump threatened Nigeria with military action and aid cessation.
Trump ordered the Pentagon to plan for potential military action in Nigeria.
The threat was made due to alleged failure to stop Christian persecution.
The Nigerian government denies the claims of not stemming atrocities.
Trump made the statements on Truth Social and in other public forums.

items.title: Tanzania's President Hassan wins disputed election with more than 97% of vote
What’s driving unrest in Tanzania after president’s landslide re-election?
items.standfirst: President Samia Suluhu Hassan has been re-elected in a landslide, as the government denies that hundreds were killed.
items.content: President Samia Suluhu Hassan has been re-elected in a landslide, as the government denies that hundreds were killed.

items.title: Tanzania's President Hassan wins contested election after crackdown on opposition
items.standfirst: Tanzania's President Samia Suluhu Hassan won the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote, according to official results announced Saturday. Her two main opponents had both been prevented from running, leaving her virtually unopposed.
items.content: Tanzania's President Samia Suluhu Hassan won the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote, according to official results announced Saturday. Her two main opponents had both been prevented from running, leaving her virtually unopposed.

items.title: Tanzania president wins election as hundreds feared dead in unrest
items.standfirst: Demonstrations continued on Friday as young protesters denounced the election as unfair.
items.content: Demonstrations continued on Friday as young protesters denounced the election as unfair.

items.title: Video: Tanzania president declared winner amid deadly election unrest
items.standfirst: Tanzania's President has been declared the winner of the country’s presidential elections amid deadly unrest.
items.content: Tanzania's President has been declared the winner of the country’s presidential elections amid deadly unrest.

items.title: Tanzanian president wins disputed election with more than 97% of the vote
items.standfirst: President Samia Suluhu Hassan won the country's disputed election with more than 97% of the vote, according to official results announced Saturday, in a rare landslide victory in the region.
items.content: President Samia Suluhu Hassan won the country's disputed election with more than 97% of the vote, according to official results announced Saturday, in a rare landslide victory in the region.(Image credit: ‎)

items.title: Tanzania’s Hassan declared landslide winner in election that triggered violent protests
items.standfirst: The result hands Hassan, who took power in 2021, a five-year term following opposition repressionTanzania’s president, Samia Suluhu Hassan, has been declared the winner of the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote following violent protests across the country earlier in the week.The landslide result announced by Tanzania’s electoral commission hands Hassan, who took power in 2021 after the death in office of her predecessor, a five-year term to govern the east African country of 68 million people. Continue reading...
items.content: The result hands Hassan, who took power in 2021, a five-year term following opposition repressionTanzania’s president, Samia Suluhu Hassan, has been declared the winner of the country’s disputed election with more than 97% of the vote following violent protests across the country earlier in the week.The landslide result announced by Tanzania’s electoral commission hands Hassan, who took power in 2021 after the death in office of her predecessor, a five-year term to govern the east African country of 68 million people. Continue reading...

ai_summary: President Samia Suluhu Hassan won the election with over 97% of the vote.
The election triggered violent protests across Tanzania.
Hassan took power in 2021 after the death of her predecessor.
Her main opponents were prevented from running in the election.
The result gives Hassan a five-year term to govern Tanzania.

clusters.title: 'Seas of people': Huge crowds rally in Novi Sad to mark train station disaster anniversary
clusters.neutral_headline: Huge Crowds Gather to Mark Train Station Disaster Anniversary

items.title: 'Seas of people': Huge crowds rally in Novi Sad to mark train station disaster anniversary
items.standfirst: "Seas of people" gathered in Serbia's Novi Sad to commemorate the deadly train station incident that killed 16 people last November, FRANCE 24's Laurent Rouy said, adding that the demonstrators are urging President Vucic's government to call snap elections.
items.content: "Seas of people" gathered in Serbia's Novi Sad to commemorate the deadly train station incident that killed 16 people last November, FRANCE 24's Laurent Rouy said, adding that the demonstrators are urging President Vucic's government to call snap elections.

items.title: Anger lingers in Serbia a year after train station tragedy
items.standfirst: Tens of thousands mourned 16 people who died in a rail station canopy collapse in Novi Sad last year, sparking ongoing protests.
items.content: Tens of thousands mourned 16 people who died in a rail station canopy collapse in Novi Sad last year, sparking ongoing protests.

items.title: Huge crowds gather on first anniversary of Serbian train station disaster
items.standfirst: Student-led movement continues to demand political change as embattled president issues rare apologyTens of thousands of Serbians have gathered to commemorate victims of a fatal railway station collapse a year ago, a tragedy that galvanised anti-government sentiment that still threatens the embattled president, Aleksandar Vučić.A student-led movement organised the rallies in the country’s second largest city, Novi Sad, where on 1 November 2024, the canopy at the newly renovated railway station collapsed. Continue reading...
items.content: Student-led movement continues to demand political change as embattled president issues rare apologyTens of thousands of Serbians have gathered to commemorate victims of a fatal railway station collapse a year ago, a tragedy that galvanised anti-government sentiment that still threatens the embattled president, Aleksandar Vučić.A student-led movement organised the rallies in the country’s second largest city, Novi Sad, where on 1 November 2024, the canopy at the newly renovated railway station collapsed. Continue reading...

items.content: Tens of thousands of people marked the first anniversary of a train station roof collapse in silence.

items.content: Large crowds converge in Novi Sad to commemorate deadly accident that has led to frequent mass antigovernment protests.

ai_summary: Tens of thousands gathered in Novi Sad to commemorate the disaster.

The collapse killed 16 people and sparked ongoing protests.
Demonstrators are urging the government to call snap elections.

clusters.title: Trump to host Syria’s al-Sharaa for talks at White House, envoy says
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump to Host Syrian President for Talks at White House

items.title: Trump to host Syria’s al-Sharaa for talks at White House, envoy says
items.standfirst: Al-Sharaa's trip, planned for November 10, will be first-ever visit by a Syrian president to the White House.
items.content: Al-Sharaa's trip, planned for November 10, will be first-ever visit by a Syrian president to the White House.

items.title: Trump will host first-ever visit by a Syrian president to the White House, official says
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump met with Syrian President Ahmad al-Sharaa in Saudi Arabia in May. The meeting was seen as a major turn of events for a Syria that is still adjusting to life after the over 50-year, iron-gripped rule of the Assad family.
items.content: President Donald Trump met with Syrian President Ahmad al-Sharaa in Saudi Arabia in May. The meeting was seen as a major turn of events for a Syria that is still adjusting to life after the over 50-year, iron-gripped rule of the Assad family.

ai_summary: Trump will host Syrian President Ahmad al-Sharaa for talks.
The visit will be the first-ever by a Syrian president to the White House.
The meeting is scheduled for November 10.
Trump met al-Sharaa in Saudi Arabia in May.
The meeting was seen as a major turn of events.

clusters.title: Daylight saving time ends Sunday. Here's what to know
clusters.neutral_headline: Daylight Saving Time Ends Sunday

items.title: Daylight saving time ends Sunday. Here's what to know
items.standfirst: Love it or hate it, many will turn their clocks back on Sunday. The debate — whether or not to make daylight saving time permanent — continues.
items.content: Love it or hate it, many will turn their clocks back on Sunday. The debate — whether or not to make daylight saving time permanent — continues.(Image credit: Charles Krupa)

items.title: Get ready to fall back: Daylight saving time ends tonight
items.standfirst: Daylight saving time ends on Sunday, Nov. 2, 2025, at 2 a.m., when the clocks "fall back" and we gain an hour.
items.content: Daylight saving time ends on Sunday, Nov. 2, 2025, at 2 a.m., when the clocks "fall back" and we gain an hour.

ai_summary: Daylight saving time ends on Sunday.
Clocks will be turned back one hour.
The debate over permanent daylight saving time continues.
Daylight saving time ends at 2 a.m.
People will gain an hour when clocks fall back.

clusters.title: Jamaica relief efforts continue in aftermath of Hurricane Melissa
clusters.neutral_headline: Relief Efforts Continue After Hurricane Melissa

items.title: Jamaica relief efforts continue in aftermath of Hurricane Melissa
items.standfirst: Rescuers and aid workers fanned out across Jamaica on Saturday to distribute food and water and reach communities still isolated four days after Hurricane Melissa hit the island.
items.content: Rescuers and aid workers fanned out across Jamaica on Saturday to distribute food and water and reach communities still isolated four days after Hurricane Melissa hit the island.

items.title: Aid workers struggle to reach communities cut off by Hurricane Melissa
items.standfirst: Rescuers and aid workers across Jamaica on Saturday are struggling to reach communities still isolated four days after Hurricane Melissa hit the island. Melissa has left devastation in its wake, snapping power lines and toppling buildings, disrupting food and water distribution and destroying crop fields.
items.content: Rescuers and aid workers across Jamaica on Saturday are struggling to reach communities still isolated four days after Hurricane Melissa hit the island. Melissa has left devastation in its wake, snapping power lines and toppling buildings, disrupting food and water distribution and destroying crop fields.

ai_summary: Relief efforts continue in Jamaica after Hurricane Melissa.
Aid workers are struggling to reach isolated communities.
Hurricane Melissa caused devastation across the island.
The hurricane snapped power lines and toppled buildings.
Food and water distribution has been disrupted.

items.content: Republican Rep. Nancy Mace was flying out of Charleston International Airport on Thursday when the incident occurred.

items.standfirst: At an airport in South Carolina on Thursday, US representative Nancy Mace called police officers “fucking incompetent” and berated them repeatedly, according to an incident report.
items.content: At an airport in South Carolina on Thursday, US representative Nancy Mace called police officers “fucking incompetent” and berated them repeatedly, according to an incident report.

clusters.title: Ukraine sends special forces to Pokrovsk as Moscow tightens grip
clusters.neutral_headline: Ukraine Deploys Forces Amidst Russian Offensive

items.title: Ukraine sends special forces to Pokrovsk as Moscow tightens grip
items.standfirst: Ukraine on Saturday deployed special forces to the eastern city of Pokrovsk, which is under an intense Russian assault. The city has been in Moscow's sights for over a year and lies on a major supply route for the Ukrainian army. Russia's army fired 270 missiles over October, up 46 percent on the previous month, according to an AFP analysis.
items.content: Ukraine on Saturday deployed special forces to the eastern city of Pokrovsk, which is under an intense Russian assault. The city has been in Moscow's sights for over a year and lies on a major supply route for the Ukrainian army. Russia's army fired 270 missiles over October, up 46 percent on the previous month, according to an AFP analysis.

items.title: Ukraine sends special forces to eastern city Pokrovsk amid Russia offensive
items.standfirst: Ukrainian army chief says effort continues 'to destroy and dislodge' Russian forces from strategic Donetsk region city.
items.content: Ukrainian army chief says effort continues 'to destroy and dislodge' Russian forces from strategic Donetsk region city.

ai_summary: Ukraine sent special forces to Pokrovsk, a city under intense Russian assault.
Pokrovsk is on a major supply route for the Ukrainian army.
Russia's missile fire increased by 46 percent in October.
Ukrainian forces are trying to destroy and dislodge Russian forces.
The effort is focused on the strategic Donetsk region.

items.title: Flights delayed across US amid air traffic controller shortages as shutdown drags on
items.standfirst: Nearly 50% of 30 busiest airports facing absences as staff are forced to work without pay and shutdown hits 31st dayNearly 50% of the 30 busiest US airports faced shortages of air traffic controllers, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said on Friday, leading to flight delays nationwide as a federal government shutdown hit its 31st day.The absence of controllers on Friday is by far the most widespread since the shutdown began, with one of the worst-hit regions being New York, where 80% of air traffic controllers were out, the agency said. Continue reading...
items.content: Nearly 50% of 30 busiest airports facing absences as staff are forced to work without pay and shutdown hits 31st dayNearly 50% of the 30 busiest US airports faced shortages of air traffic controllers, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said on Friday, leading to flight delays nationwide as a federal government shutdown hit its 31st day.The absence of controllers on Friday is by far the most widespread since the shutdown began, with one of the worst-hit regions being New York, where 80% of air traffic controllers were out, the agency said. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Flight delays and cancellations are impacting major US airports.
Air traffic controller shortages are causing disruptions nationwide.
Nearly 50% of the 30 busiest airports are facing staff absences.
New York area airports are experiencing significant delays.
The government shutdown has lasted for 31 days.

clusters.title: Man killed in South Yorkshire helicopter crash named as Peter Smith
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Identified After Fatal Helicopter Crash

items.title: Man killed in South Yorkshire helicopter crash named as Peter Smith
items.standfirst: Seventy-year-old, who died in incident near Bentley, said by family to be ‘a beloved husband, father and grandfather’A man who was killed in a helicopter crash in Doncaster, South Yorkshire on Thursday has been named by his family as Peter Smith.The family described Smith, 70, as “a beloved husband, father and grandfather” and said they were “all devastated by this sudden loss”, in a statement released by South Yorkshire police. Continue reading...

Continue reading...
